listWit.witness: London, British Museum Royal 10 A I

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of this text has followed the recommendations of the LombardPress 1.0.0 guidelines for a critical edition.

change.p: File Started for the first time.

div.p:
Nunc vero de omnipotentia
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 42, xxx
. This is distinction 42 in which, after the Master treated the true and infallible knowledge of God, now he begins to treat about his immense and unending power.

And this is divided into three parts because in the first place he introduces the question and solves it, in the second place against the response he makes a different objection, in the third place he offers something notable from which one is able to elicit a true conclusion. The second part begins at
sed quaeritur
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 42, xxx
. The third part begins at
hic diligenter
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 42, xxx
.

The first is divided into three according to a threefold objection while adding a response to whichever. The second begins at
sed alia sunt quaedam
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 42, xxx
. The third begins at
sunt etiam et alia
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 42, xxx
.

From the above the next part follows which is divided into three, for he argues in the first place form authorities, in the second place he reveals the understanding of them, in the third place he objects to the exposition of them. The second begins at
sed adhuc
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 42, xxx
. The third begins at
se de forte dices
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 42, xxx
, etc. And this is the division, etc.
Whether the adequate ratio of omnipotence is the immeasurable activity of the divine essence?

In the first place, that is not because, if there were some omnipotence, then this would be reducible to act. But this is false because then there would be some infinite passive potency corresponding to it. The consequence is clear because any potency which is not able to be reduced to act is without purpose.

In the second place, if something were omnipotent, then it would be able to cause motion in an instant. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because nothing would be able to resist omnipotence, but succession in motion is caused from resistance, therefore.

In the third place, God is not omnipotent with respect to every thing possible, therefore. The antecedent is proved both because he is not able to earn merit or to sin, and because he is not the power of every power since the divine person is not a power over another person nor the essence over a person, and also because he is not able to immediately supply a replacement for each second cause.

In opposition is the
Master
Lombardus, Sent. I, c. 42, xxx
citing
Augustine in this distinction
Augustine,
.

First conclusion: though it may be that something is omnipotent and that it does not have in itself every power formally, nevertheless it is necessary that the one and only first producer of all things has power according to virtue, grade, and vigor. The first part of the conclusion is proved because God is omnipotent and does not have every power in himself formally, therefore the conclusion is true. The first part of the antecedent is clear. The second is proved because some powers are called imperfections, therefore they should not be put in God formally but only virtually. The antecedent is clear from passive potencies. Again the antecedent is proved from the active potencies of creatures which have a joined imperfection and limitation, and consequently ought not to be put in God formally but only virtually, just as the potency of running, eating, speaking, and similar kinds of potencies. But potencies of willing and understanding are in God formally and are God because they are and they refer to a perfection absolutely.
The second part of the conclusion is proved through
Dionysius, On the divine names, in the last chapter , where he says,
divine virtue is the from which, through which, in which, and to which all things are
Ps-Dionysius, De divinis nominibus, xxx , and he concludes,
it is necessary for us to praise the one divine virtue and cause of all things
Ps-Dionysius, De divinis nominibus, xxx . Again, chapter 10, he says,
divine virtue contains and gathers all things through ordering, strengthens through conserving, and from itself as if from a root produces all things and converts all things to itself
Ps-Dionysius, De divinis nominibus, xxx . These are the things Dionysius says there, from which words the second part of the conclusion is clear.

First corollary: no one explains divine omnipotence well and sufficiently as the power to do whatever does not imply a contradiction. This is clear because a sin is doable, and nevertheless God is not able to do it, therefore.

Second corollary: to the degree that it is necessary that the creature is possible so to the same degree it is necessary that the creature is makable by omnipotence. This is clear because it follows, no creature is able to be, therefore no power is able to make the creature to be, therefore divine omnipotence is not able to make the creature to be.

Third corollary: it is the case that something is omnipotent and not be sufficiently powerful for something producible. This is clear because if this is not so, then the Son would not be omnipotent since he is not able generatively to produce himself, and this similarly the case for the Holy Spirit.

Second conclusion: though through the infinite immensity and through the immeasurable infinity of power with respect any existing or producible that is not indicating an imperfect the ratio of the supreme being should be inferred, nevertheless no producible effect produced or created is or is able to be an adequate term to divine omnipotence. The first part is proved for it is not the case that some being is in this way and is not the omnipotent God, therefore. The antecedent is proved through
Wisdom 7
which says
since it is one, it is able to do all things
Sapientia 7:27 . Again,
Luke 2
no word is impossible with God
Lucas 1:37 . Again, this is clear through
Dionysius, De divinis nominibus,
chapter 8 , where he says,
the power of God is infinite because he is able to produce infinite things
Ps-Dionysius, De divinibus nominibus, xxx
. Again, this is clear through
Alanum De maximis theologiae, rule 51 , where he says,
only he is omnipotent who is able to do all things which are able to be something that is possible
Alanus de Insulis, De maximis theologiae, xxx
. Again, note that part of the ratio of omnipotence is that it is free, from which it is clear that to say omnipotence is to say something more than infinite power. Whence, if there were an infinite power and it were not free, then this would not be omnipotence. The second part of the conclusion is proved because, if thus, it follows that when such a thing is produced into existence God would not be able to produce something unless he would destroy that either completely or in part. The consequent seems inconvenient. The consequences is clear because since this effect would be adequate to divine omnipotence, it would contain every perfection able to be produced. Or, if it did not contain every such perfection, it follows that the term would not be adequate to the thing which is opposed to what has been posited, therefore the conclusion is true.
First corollary: in a line or latitude of producible things it is necessary that something is unproduced

The second corollary: an imaginable line of producible perfections going upward is infinite having now terminus This is clear because otherwise there would be given supreme perfection externally producible, and thus there would be given adequate term for omnipotence, which is disproved above.

A sub-corollary, it follows, from the production from any effect however small, it is sufficiently inferred the immensity of the first principle. This is clear because from what sort of things in such production the independence of the first principle is able to be argued.

Third corollary: that this consequence is not a good explication of omnipotence, whatever occurs from some omnipotent being does not imply a contradiction, God is able to do and only this, against
Hugolinum, distinction 42 of book 1, article one . This is clear because when speaking loosely according to him the Son of God is able to become in some mode from some omnipotent being, namely from the Father and not from the Holy Spirit, nor from itself. Again to speak thus is to argue in a circle and to say that, therefore it is omnipotent because it is omnipotent.

Third conclusion: just as the divine immensity is able to effect every possible dependence that could be made, so the immense activity is able to produce whatever the creature is able to produce equivalently according to species and measure. The first part is clear through what has been said. The second part is clear because the second cause is not possible unless in virtue of the first. Again, the first cause is able to produce casually independently and just as easily in an instant as in time, which the creature is not able to do. This is also clear from the things said by Dionysius stated above.

First corollary: whatever is a perfection able to be produced from a second cause this is able to be produced by an omnipotent being in an infinitely more perfect mode. This is clear because God in an independent mode is able to do what some second cause is not able to do.

Second corollary: a single immense and omnipotent power is every perfect power being super-equivalently equivalent. This is clear because this power is able to do whatever any other power is able to do and in whatever degree, this power exceeds it according to the species and the measure of the action.

Third corollary: just as without the activity of an omnipotent being nothing is able to be produced, so from this every productive ratio of a second cause is able to be immediately supplied. This is clear because every power is equivalently and prevalently powerful. From what has been said the affirmative part of the conclusion is clear

Against the first conclusion: it is argued in the first argument made at the end of the conclusion that this potential for act is not reproducible, therefore. The consequence holds through the
Philosopher , and the antecedent is proved because then it would be possible to give an adequate term to it, which is against the
second conclusion .

In the second place, because motion would be able to occurr in an instant, which implies a contradiction because the ratio of motion is that it a part and divisible succession because it is acquired part after part

In the third place, it follows that God would have the power of sinning or at least equivalently. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear since this
seems to be some power.

Against the second conclusion, because, if this were true, it would follows that the creature would be omnipotent. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because the creature is able to produce infinite things. Again, to spirate is contained under omnipotence and does not indicate an imperfection, therefore.
In the second place, thus, God is not able to make the impossible to be possible, therefore there is for him something impossible.

In the third place, it does not imply that there is or will be an infinite multitude and an infinite magnitude and an infinite quality, therefore something is able to be an adequate term for omnipotence. The consequence holds because divine omnipotence is not greater than infinity. And the antecedent is proved because God is able to make charity is the first half of this hour of a certain intension and immediately make an equal half, and thus consequently through the entire hour speed continues its action and while producing infinite equal portions according to the proportional parts of the hour according to proportional parts of the hour, and it happens that at the end of the hour infinitely intensive charity is produced. And in this way it would be able to be argued about other things.

Against the third conclusion, if the divine immensity were omnipotent in this way, then either he would be able to make the paster never to have been, or not. If he were so able, then God would be able to make the first instant of the world to be nothing by destroying it, and then it would be asked whether whether these were young or old and when they were produced.
Again, then we would have to doubt whether Christ was incarnate and suffered, and thus about all things past.

Again, then two instances would be able to be immediate things, which is denied by the
Philosopher VI Physics
Aristoteles, Physica XXX
. See
Iohannes Clenkoc
XXX
.

Again, if God were to make it that Adam never existed, it follows that he would also make it that Abel never existed or it is asked about Abel what he was and whose son he was, see
Magister Hugolinus, in this distinction
XXX .

But if the second
is granted, against this argues
Our Gregory XXX , and
Clienton
XXX
and many others because, if it is necessary that the past is past, then it is asked from which part this is necessary?
Secundo, quia hoc non claudit contra dictionem mundus non fuit et Deus est igitur Deus potest verificare illam co?vam simul.
Tertio, quia non minus potens est Deus post rei lapsum in praeteritum quam ante sed ante sed ante potuit ergo et nunc.

Ad primam, negatur consequentia quia Deus ad nullum finem extrinsecum praeter se ordidus est ideo si Deus adextra / nihil produceret vel ageret adhuc eius omnipotentia non esset frustra quia illud dicitur frustra esse quando non ordinatur ad finem ad quem debet ordinari.

Secundo, posset dici quod reducitur ad actum intrinsecum perfecte quia producit terminum immensum. Ad hoc autem quod dicit Philosophus quod potentiae active correspondet potentia passiva illud verum est de potentiis finitis et limitis et dicitur quod modus arguendi non valet. Patet quia similiter posset argui Deus ab aeterno habuit potentiam me producendi igitur frustra eam habuit patet enim quod consequentia non valet.
Ad secundam, primo posset negari consequentia loquendo de motu proprie.
Secundo, dicitur quod si motus sumeretur large pro quacumque mutatione posset concedi consequens, et tunc diceretur quod de ratione motus sic sumpti non est habere successionem.
Tertio, dicitur quod si primus motor esset virtutis infinitae adhuc non sequitur motum fieri in instanti quia talis motor est agens liberum, et per consequens posset movere certo gradu velociter.

Ad tertiam, neganda
consequentia et ad probationem dicitur quod posse peccare non est posse nec efficere si sic deficere. Item peccare dicit imperfectionem, ideo non cadit sub obiecto omnipotente.

Ad primam contra secundam conclusionem, negatur consequentia, et ad probationem dicitur quod supposito quod creatura posset producere infinita, non tamen propria virtute et independenter a nullo extrinseco actuata sicut Deus.

Ad secundam, posset negari consequentia quia in his quae implicant contradictionem convenientius dicitur quod non possunt fieri quam Deus non potest illa facere, nec tamen propter hoc debet dici aliquod verbum impossibile apud Deum quia impossibile non dicitur verbum cum proprie dici vel intelligi non possit, ideo impossibilia non repugnant nec infringunt veritatem illius dicti.
Ad aliud, dicitur quod sumendo fieri pro effective effici sic Spiritus Sanctus nec Filius possunt fieri, licet producantur.

Secundo, posset dici secundum
Thomam
Aquinas, xxx
et
Aegidium Nostrum Aegidius Romanos, xxx
quod spirare non comprehenditur sub omnipotentia simpliciter et absolute sed sub omnipotentia Patris et Filii et non Spiritus Sancti propter repugnantiam habitudinis terminorum vel praedicati ad subiectum.

Ad tertiam, negatur consequentia quia dato quod illa multitudo magnitudo se qualitas sit aliquo modo infinita, tamen quia est limitata et dependens, ideo simpliciter non est infinita, et ergo non adaequat potentiam divinam.

Secundo, pro materia argumenti dicitur quod, licet Deus posset producere infinita, non tamen potest producere infinitum numerum. Prima patet quia Deus potest causare immediate prima horae unum angelum et in secunda proportionali unum alium, et sic consequenter eos conservando.
Tertio, dicitur quod si foret aliquod corpus infinitum secundum omnem dimensionem, non posset moveri motu recto sed circulari nec oportet in motu locali mutare locum.
Quarto, dicitur quod Deus posset ponere corpus in eodem loco cum priori, immo infinita talia posset Deus ponere in eodem loco.

Ad primam contra tertiam conclusionem, dicitur quod utraque pars adversis tenetur et rationes utriusque partis solvuntur. Ideo qui vellet tenere quod sic posset dicere ad rationem primam opinionis oppositae negando consequentia sic intelligendo consequens quod Deus conservaret omnes homines et vellet numquam fuisset tempus quia
secundum opinionem Iacobi de Viterbio
Iacobus de Viterbio
quaelibet res creata est finis temporalis morosus fluxus. Alio modo posset intelligi consequens nullum hominem destruendo, id est vellet nullum hominem esse vel fuisse, et sic consequentia et consequens possunt concedi.

To the second, the consequence is denied because in this way it could also be said about an article regarding the future because the church equally believes the past and future, and equally commands that they are believed in such a way that we do not have a doubt about any article.
To the third, the consequence is able to be denied. In the second place, it is said that while the consequent is conceded nothing impossible follows.

Ad quartam, de Abel dicitur quod sicut Deus posset facere quod ille qui fuit pater meus potest velle quod numquam fuerit pater meus sic potest velle quod unus qui numquam fuit pater meus esset pater meus.
Ad primam alterius partis, diceretur quod talis necessaris praeteritionis est ex parte lapsus temporis.
Ad secundam, negatur antecedens quia illa copulativa implicat.
Ad tertiam, negatur consequentia.

Nunc vero de omnipotentia
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
. Prima conclusio: quod Deus trinitas est opus quia potest omnia quae possibilia sunt
posse vel quae convenit ei posse.

Secunda conclusio: quod Deus potest quaedam per se facere ut creare caelum quaedam potest facere non in se sed in creaturis ut motum quaedam dicitur non posse ut peccare pati falli et mori quia huius posse non est potentiae sed infirmitatis Deus enim omnia potest facere sed non facit nisi quod convenit veritati eius et iustitiae.

Tertia conclusio: quod Deus a se et per se omnia potest creatura vero nec a se nec per se potest aliquid Filius Dei per se potest sed non a se quia non habet a se quod possit omnia sed a Patre a quo habet esse simili et Spiritus Sanctus.

Quarta conclusio: quod Deus potest facere quidquid vult fieri et potest quidquid vult se posse et econverso vult se posse quidquid potest, non tamen omne quod vult se posse facere vult fieri quia tunc omne quod facere posset fieret cum voluntas eius sit omnipotens nec aliquid ei resistere possit.

Et notandum est non ideo dicitur Deus omnipotens quia
quia
potest quidquid vult facere quia tunc quilibet beatus esset omnipotens quia potest facere quidquid vult fieri et quidquid vult se posse.
